title: RL31866
content: President Bush signed the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 into law on July 30, 2002, in response to the Enron Corporation bankruptcy. The act established the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board to regulate corporate auditors and imposed restrictions on accounting firms. It also introduced new disclosure requirements for public companies and their officers, addressed securities fraud, imposed penalties for violating securities laws, and provided protections for corporate whistleblowers. Ongoing criminal prosecutions aim to enhance corporate accountability. President Bush signed the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 into law on July 30, 2002, in response to the Enron Corporation bankruptcy. The act aimed to improve corporate accountability by establishing new legal and regulatory standards for corporate behavior. Criminal charges have been filed against firms and individuals associated with high-profile cases since Enron's collapse, with some resulting in civil indictments. Post-Enron criminal charges are listed in a CRS report. The table in the CorporateScandals report lists charges, indictments, and guilty pleas in corporate scandals since Enron, including some cases with civil indictments.
